description: Strand units: Spatial awareness, 2-D shapes, 3-D shapes, Symmetry and Angles

teaching.topicContent: Introduce hexagons as shapes with six sides and angles. Describe the attributes of hexagons and how they differ from triangles and rectangles.

Introduce irregular shapes that don't have equal sides or angles.Discuss how irregular shapes can vary in their attributes. Identify and compare irregular shapes in the environment, like clouds and leaves..
Introduce pentagons as shapes with five sides and five angles.Discuss real-world examples of pentagons, such as home plate in baseball. Explore the symmetry and attributes of pentagons.
Introduce octagons as shapes with eight sides and angles.Discuss where octagons are commonly found, like stop signs.Compare octagons with other polygons in terms of sides and angles.

teaching.topicTitle: Lesson: Marveling at Circles and Semicircles
teaching.topicContent: Explore circles as round shapes with curved edges and no corners.Discuss how a semicircle is half of a circle and its unique attributes.Identify examples of circles and semicircles in everyday objects.
Introduce ovals as elongated round shapes with curved edges.Discuss the difference between ovals and circles. Explore how ellipses are stretched circles and their use in design.

Provide students with various 2-D shapes, including those not mentioned earlier. Have them create shape collages using a variety of shapes and sizes.Encourage creative arrangement and discussion of shapes' attributes.

Introduce tessellations, where shapes fit together without gaps or overlaps. Provide students with shape templates and have them design tessellating patterns. Discuss the use of tessellations in art and architecture.
Take students on an art walk around the school or community.Identify and discuss different 2-D   Encourage students to observe how shapes contribute to the overall design.
Create bingo cards with various 2-D shapes.Call out attributes of shapes, and students mark the corresponding shape on their cards.Reinforce shape recognition and properties through a fun game.

Discuss lines of symmetry in shapes, including those mentioned earlier.Engage students in hands-on activities to fold shapes and identify lines of symmetry. Have students draw and label lines of symmetry in various shapes.

Provide students with a set of shapes, including those mentioned earlier. Have them compare and analyze the properties of different shapes. Encourage discussions on which shapes have more sides, angles, or symmetry.

test.description: Put your Strand of Shape knowledge to the test.

questions.content: How many sides does a hexagon have?
What term is used to describe shapes that don't have equal sides or angles?
How many sides does a pentagon have?
How many sides does an octagon have?
What shape is described as round with curved edges and no corners?
What term is used to describe elongated round shapes with curved edges?
In a tessellation, how do shapes fit together?
What type of shape has exactly one line of symmetry?
What term is used for shapes that have the same shape and size?
What is the name of a shape with eight sides and angles?
What term is used to describe a stretched circle?
What is the primary characteristic of irregular shapes?
